title: UK's pre-Christmas election hopes to unwrap Brexit
text:
The UK is heading towards a pre-Christmas election after Prime Minister's Boris Johnson's bid to break a Brexit deadlock received backing from opposition parties.

The leader of the Labour Party Jeremy Corbyn had opposed an election while a "no-deal Brexit" was still on the table.

But with the EU is now finalizing the UK's third extension to Brexit - until the end of January - Corbyn said that condition was now met.

(SOUNDBITE) (English) UK OPPOSITION LEADER, JEREMY CORBYN, SAYING:

"We are ready for an election. We're going to go out there with a very strong message of how we transform our society to end inequality and injustice, and deal with the devastating poverty that so many people face."

Parliament voted against Johnson's demand for a third election on Monday (October 28) but on Tuesday (October 29) he will try and push through a bill, calling for an election on December 12, that requires a simple majority.

Lawmakers could still bring significant changes to that bill, including over the date and whether to allow settled EU citizens a vote.

Johnson says the poll is needed to end what he casts as a nightmare paralysis that prevents any Brexit outcome at all.

But the UK's first Christmas election since 1923 would be highly unpredictable; Brexit has fatigued and enraged swathes of voters while eroding traditional loyalties to the two main parties.

Ultimately, it could boil down to a choice between an emboldened Johnson with a mandate for his Brexit deal, or a socialist government under Corbyn renegotiating the deal before a referendum.

If no party wins conclusively, however, the Brexit deadlock could continue.
